comments.text:
So I love unique testing/tracing methods. Very good use of a tone generator!

One time had a customer with a similar issue, we had a cable broken in the floor heating circuit run. Just so happens the shop I worked for also did high voltage and substation work too, and we had an 80kV old school Hi-pot tester. We had some continuity but the resistance was very high. We figured we could weld the wires back together with an 80,000v pulse from the test set, and it worked! Then we used a Variac to send some current through the new connection we burnt, and scanned the floor with a hi-res infrared camera. Immediately isolated the break point and homeowner only had to replace one tile. Love it!
comments.author: @TheDaftWilliam

comments.text:
Ah, good old Federal No-Blo breakers.

I was identifying breakers and outlet circuits on one job by putting shorting jumpers in each outlet, then looking for continuity at the panel.  I had forgotten to remove the jumper from one outlet, and turned its breaker on - It just sat there and hummed, but never tripped.

Add to this that the "on" position is toward the outside, so it pulled the stablok connection off the bus every time unless the cover was on.

These things sucked way too long before they were finally pulled by code.
comments.author: @studworth
